questions.text: What kind of wound is an open cardiac massage?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Description

Class I

Clean

An uninfected operative wound with no inflammation and no entry into the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts. Wounds are primarily closed, and drainage is closed if needed.

Class II Clean-Contaminated

An operative wound where the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Includes operations like biliary tract, appendix, vagina, and oropharynx.

Class III

Contaminated

Open, fresh accidental wounds or operations with major breaks in sterile technique

(open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract, with acute non-purulent inflammation.

Class IV

Dirty-Infected

Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue, clinical infection, or perforated viscera. The organisms causing postoperative infection were already present in the operative field before the operation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, bluish nodules on the skin with no infections are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Complications

Explanations

Lymphedema

Swelling is caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm or chest wall due to the removal of lymph nodes.(After MRM and axillary dissection)

Wound infection/Flap necrosis

Postoperative infections where blackening of suture line is seen (flap necrosis), if necrosed site note removed, leads to wound infection

Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome

Chronic pain in the chest or upper arm due to nerve damage or scar tissue formation.

Nerve Injuries
  • Long thoracic nerve- injury leads to winging of the scapula
  • Thoracodorsal nerve

Lymphangiosarcoma
  • Stewart-Treves syndrome - Cancerous growth in the lymphatic vessels, often associated with long-standing lymphedema.
  • After an average of 10.5 years following MRM and radiotherapy, the patient develops angiosarcoma

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with shock and hypotension. The extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative, the X-ray is normal, and the ECG shows no abnormalities. The patient's SpO2 is 93%, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and pulse rate is 40/min. Based on this information, what type of shock is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Type of Shock

Cardiac Output

Systemic Vascular Resistance

Central Venous Pressure

Mean Arterial Pressure

Hypovolemic

↓

↑

↓

↓

Cardiogenic

↓

↑

↑

↓

Distributive(Septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic)

↑ or ↓

↓

↓ or N

↓

Obstructive (pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)

↓

↑

↑

↓

questions.text: In patients at risk of refeeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
One or more of the following: (OR)

Two or more of the following:

BMI <16 kg/m2

BMI <18.5 kg/m2

Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months

Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months.

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days.

Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics.

questions.text: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the image:
questions.explanation:
Type of edges

Clinical conditions

Details

Sloping edge
  • Healing ulcer
  • Varicose ulcer
  • Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue)
  • Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation)
  • Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue)

Undermined edge
  • Tubercular ulcers

Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue), whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards

Punched out edge
  • Arterial / Ischemic ulcers
  • Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer
  • Trophic ulcer

Due to endarteritis

Raised & beaded edge

Rolled out /

Pearly white edge
  • Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma

Beads are due to proliferating active cells

 

Pearly white in appearance

Everted edge /

Rolled out edge
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident (RTA) with a crush injury presents with crepitus and a reddish-brown wound within 3 days after amputation. What is the most likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Gas Gangrene

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus.

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence:
Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.correct_answer: C. Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

questions.text: An elderly chronic smoker male is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip with no lymph node involvement. What is the treatment of choice?

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local excision with negative borders

options.label: D
options.text: Wide local excision with frozen section

questions.correct_answer: D. Wide local excision with frozen section

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention?
questions.explanation:
Colour

Priority

Medical Need

Clinical Status

Examples

Red

 

First

Immediate

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural haematomas

Yellow (Option B)

 

Second

Urgent

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries

Green (Option C)

 

Third

Non-Urgent

Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations

Black (Option D)

Last

Unsalvageable

Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help.
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/ loss of chest or abdominal wall structures

questions.text: What type of skin graft is used in the image shown?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Thiersch Graft  (Split-Thickness Skin Graft)

Wolfe Graft  (Full-Thickness Skin Graft)

Type of Skin Grafting

Split-thickness

Full-thickness

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction

Significant contraction, leading to poor cosmetic appearance

Lesser contraction, better cosmetic appearance

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.text: A female patient presents to the outpatient department 10 days postpartum with complaints of a fluctuant breast mass with tenderness, high-grade fever, and cracked nipples. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with chronic pancreatitis undergoes a Puestow procedure. What is the most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation:
3 in 1 formulation

2 in 1 formulation

Solutions with lipids (Option C)

Solutions without lipids

60/20/20

  • 60% by dextrose
  • 20% by amino acids
  • 20% by fat.

75/25

  • 75% by dextrose
  • 25% by amino acids
  • No lipids used

Fiber is absent in both formulations

Line Insertion Complications
  • Pneumothorax (most dangerous)
  • Misplacement of catheter

Line-Related Complications
  • Sepsis (most common)
  • Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome)

Metabolic Complications
  • Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia)
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Metabolic bone disease
  • Vitamin deficiencies

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked in the image.
questions.explanation:
Incision Type

Description

Common Uses

Abdominal Incisions

Midline

Longitudinal cut through the linea alba, bloodless access

Exploratory laparotomy, trauma surgery, emergency surgeries

Periumbilical

Incisions around the umbilicus, avoiding the umbilical stalk

Laparoscopy, umbilical hernia repairs, postpartum tubal ligation

Pararectus

Along the semilunar line, lateral to the rectus abdominis

Abdominal wall hernia repairs, stoma creation, pelvic surgeries

Paramedian

Lateral to the linea alba, access to lateral viscera

Lateral abdominal structures,

Reduced hernia risk

Kocher/Subcostal

Inferior and parallel to the costal margin, access to upper abdomen structures

Gallbladder, biliary tree, pancreas, liver transplants, epigastric surgeries

Gridiron/

McBurney/

Lanz

Lower abdomen incisions, typically for appendectomy

Appendectomy (right side), sigmoid diverticulitis (left side), cosmetic appendectomy

Thoracoabdominal

From 7th intercostal space to the umbilicus, exposes thoracic and abdominal organs

Retroperitoneal masses, pleural space, distal oesophagus, abdominal organs

Thoracic Incisions

Thoracotomy

Access to thoracic structures, various approaches

Lung transplants, cardiac surgeries, trauma

Median Sternotomy

Vertical incision dividing the sternum, wide access to the mediastinum

Open-heart surgery, anterior mediastinal tumour resection

Trapdoor

Complex incision, supraclavicular, sternal, and thoracotomy components

Penetrating trauma, aortic arch aneurysms, complex cardiovascular access

Infraclavicular

A transverse incision just below the clavicle for subclavian vessel access

Thoracic outlet syndrome, subclavian vessel surgeries

Supraclavicular

Superior to the clavicle, providing access to the subclavian vessels

Trauma, thoracic outlet syndrome

Neck Incisions

Collar

Incision above the sternal notch for thyroid surgeries

Thyroid surgery, mid-neck structures

Traumatic Neck

Along the sternocleidomastoid muscle for trauma

Vascular or traumatic neck injuries

Tracheostomy

Vertical/horizontal incision superior to the thyroid for tracheostomy

Airway management in patients needing long-term ventilation

Pelvic Incisions

Pfannenstiel

Transverse incision above the pubic symphysis

Cesarean section, pelvic, urologic, and orthopaedic surgeries

Maylard/Cherney

Above pubic tubercle provides access to pelvic structures

Hysterectomy, pelvic lymph node dissection, lower pelvis surgeries

Inguinal

Above and parallel to the inguinal ligament

Inguinal hernia repair, urologic surgeries (cryptorchidism, varicocele)

McEvedy

Vertical incision for femoral hernia repair

Femoral hernia repair (obsolete now due to high hernia recurrence rate)

Gibson

Above inguinal ligament, arc to the lateral rectus sheath

Kidney transplantation, retroperitoneal access (iliac vessels, ureter)

questions.text: Identify the test provided in the image below.
Smoking increases the risk of which of the following diseases? Duct ectasia Fibroadenoma Mondor disease Breast carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Modifiable risk factors

Non-modifiable risk factors

Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29)

Age

  • Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK, USA), While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.

Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years

Sex

  • Female sex is a risk factor
  • Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer

Breastfeeding is a protective factor

Ethnicity

American white, African-American Parsi in India

Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2)

Family history of breast cancer

  • 1 first-degree relative RR= 2
  • 2 first-degree relative RR= 3

Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14)

Genetic predisposition

BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers

Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32)

Early Menarche(<12years)

Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19

Radiation exposure (RR=6)

Late Menopause(>55years)

Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12

Age at first child

 

  • <20years - Less risk
  • >35years - High risk

High-risk breast lesions

  • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
  • Papillomatosis RR=3
  • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident (RTA) with suspected pelvic fractures. On examination, he is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the earliest treatment for control of haemorrhage in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.correct_answer: C. Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.text: A soldier arrives at a referral hospital 24 hours after experiencing a shrapnel injury to his right thigh caused by a high-speed projectile. He expresses significant discomfort at the site of the wound. Upon examination, there is evidence of crepitus. Which of the following microorganisms is the probable culprit behind his current state?
questions.explanation:
A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens (Option D)

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues).

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound.

Occurrence

Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Types

 
  1. Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat.
  2. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera).

Risk Factors

General:

  • Malnourishment
  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Renal failure
  • Jaundice
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Treatment with steroids
  • Emergency surgery

Local:

  • Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension
  • Poor local wound healing
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure

Clinical Presentation
  • Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), (Option A)
  • Possible evisceration,
  • Popping sensation during straining or coughing.

Treatment

  • Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised.
  • Complete dehiscence with evisceration:
    • Requires urgent reoperation.
    • Tension suturing is done.
    • Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury.
    • Antibiotic therapy; fluid management.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in the management of a 30-year-old breastfeeding mother who is experiencing pain and fever in her left breast? The left breast appears abnormal as depicted in the provided image. There is slight swelling of the lymph nodes in the armpit on the affected side, while the opposite breast appears normal. Despite multiple attempts at draining the fluid with the use of antibiotics, it was unsuccessful. An ultrasound examination revealed the presence of fluid collection.

A barber aged 42 years presented with a healed ulcer as below, over the lower medial aspect of the right leg. On examination, he has varicose veins on both his legs. What is the most likely type of ulcer he had?
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

(Option C)

Arterial ulcer

(Option B)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

 

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, and distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

It is also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: False regarding deep second-degree burns:
questions.explanation:
Deep Partial-Thickness Burns

Affected Area

Epidermis and reticular dermis (bottom layer of dermis) (Option C ruled out).

Clinical Features
  • Painful
  • Loss of epidermis
  • Less moist dermis
  • Fixed capillary staining
  • Reduced sensation
  • No blanching with pressure (Option B ruled out)

Healing

Takes 3+ weeks: often leads to scarring (Option A ruled out)

Treatment

May require surgical intervention (e.g., skin grafting)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.explanation:
Carbuncle

Definition

Infection of hair follicles extending into surrounding and subcutaneous tissue.

Cause

Staphylococcus aureus.

Common Sites

Nape of neck, back.

Symptoms

Red, painful nodule; tender, fluctuant lesion; multiple draining sinuses; fever, lymphadenopathy.

Complications

Septicemia, abscess, necrosis, requiring possible excision or skin graft.

Treatment

Control of diabetes; antibiotics; drainage, debridement, possible excision.

questions.text: What is the ideal pressure setting for vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - 125 mm Hg

questions.text: An 84-year-old man who had a stroke 2 years ago and has been on extended bed rest, develops a pressure ulcer with partial skin thickness loss and a clean base. What is the grade of his pressure sore?
questions.explanation:
Pressure sore stages

Stage I

(Option A ruled out)

Early superficial ulcer

Non blanchable erythema of the skin, without breach in the epidermis

Stage II

(Option B)

Late superficial ulcer

Partial thickness, less including epidermis + dermis

Stage III

(Option C ruled out)

Early deep ulcer

Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissues but not through underlying fascia

Stage IV

(Option D ruled out)

Late deep ulcer

Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle, bone, joints or tendon.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male had surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to significant contamination, only the sheath was sutured, leaving the wound open. Daily wound irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What type of wound-healing mechanism is occurring in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Wound healing

Healing by primary intention

(Option A ruled out)

It occurs when the edges of a clean wound are brought together and secured with sutures, staples, or adhesives. Minimal scarring occurs.

Healing by secondary intention

(Option B ruled out)

The wound is left open to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialisation. This is common in wounds with significant tissue loss or contamination.

Healing by tertiary intention (delayed primary closure)

(Option C)

The wound is initially left open and then closed surgically after several days when it's clean and granulating. This is used for contaminated wounds to prevent infection.

No

questions.text: A woman, a few weeks after delivery, complains of bloody discharge from nipple and fever. On examination, diffuse lump under areola. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Lactational Mastitis

Etiology

Bacterial infection due to milk stasis (commonly Staphylococcus aureus)

Risk Factors

Breastfeeding, nipple trauma (cracks), poor latch, prolonged engorgement

Symptoms

Fever, malaise, painful swollen breast, erythema, bloody or purulent discharge

Examination

Tender indurated mass, warmth, erythema over the affected breast

Complications

Breast abscess (if untreated)

Management

Frequent breastfeeding, warm compress, analgesics, antibiotics (dicloxacillin, cephalexin)

questions.text: A patient with dilated tortuous veins of the leg presented to the OPD and is diagnosed with varicose vein of grade C4a. What is the best preferred treatment?
questions.explanation:
CEAP Class

Clinical Features

Preferred Treatment

C0

No visible/palpable signs

No treatment needed

C1

Telangiectasias or reticular veins

Conservative (compression)

C2

Varicose veins

Compression, ablation, or surgery

C3

Edema

Endothermal ablation

C4a

Pigmentation/eczema

Endothermal ablation

C4b

Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

Endothermal or open surgery

C5

Healed venous ulcer

Endothermal ablation + ulcer care

C6

Active venous ulcer

Multimodal therapy

questions.text: The ureter is safe in which type of hysterectomy?
questions.explanation:
Hysterectomy Type

Ureteric Injury Risk

Reasons

Open laparotomy

Moderate

Direct ureteric handling, risk during ligation

Laparoscopic

High

Increased risk due to thermal and traction injuries

Robotic

Moderate to high

Similar to laparoscopic but better visualization

Vaginal

Lowest

Minimal ureteric dissection, lower risk of injury

questions.text: Identify the grade of the condition given in the image below ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Grade 4

Stage I

Stage II

Stage III

Stage IV
  • Non blanchable erythema of skin without breach in epidermis
  • Early superficial ulcer
  • Partial thickness less including epidermis + dermis.
  • Late superficial ulcer
  • Full thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous through underlying fasica.
  • Early deep ulcer
  • Full thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle tendon.
  • Late deep ulcer

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident presents to the emergency department. His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On examination, breath sounds are absent on the right side. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway

options.label: B
options.text: Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line

options.label: C
options.text: Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head

options.label: D
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head

questions.correct_answer: B. Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line

questions.text: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. An ultrasound (USG) shows distention of the portal vein, and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been administered. What is the next appropriate step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement

options.label: D
options.text: Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.correct_answer: C. Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a sepsis patient in the ICU?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Hyperg

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Type

History

Lesion Characteristics

Pain

Ischemic/Arterial

Smoking, intermittent claudication

Irregular edges, poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation

Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency

Venous

Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies

Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate

Mild; relieved by elevation

Neurotrophic

Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM

Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone

None

Malignant Ulcer

History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma)

Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumor with hard, indurated tissue

Often painful, can be associated with bleeding or foul odor

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who is receiving cyclosporine A following renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of the treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a swelling in the back of his neck that has been present for almost a year. The swelling has not increased in size. On examination, it is non-pulsatile, and the slip sign is positive, with the swelling measuring 3x3 cm. Which of the following statements is most likely true?

options.label: D
options.text: Excision can be done if the patient requests it

questions.correct_answer: D. Excision can be done if the patient requests it

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He has a history of electric burns to the scalp 8 years ago. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: B
options.text: It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Long-duration antibiotics will improve the condition.

questions.correct_answer: B. It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition
  • Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice

Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by a flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (Option A) (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe pain and swelling in her right hand, which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury in the garden 5 days ago. On examination, she cries out in pain when her hand is extended and when the palmar aspect is palpated passively. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand

options.label: B
options.text: X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients

options.label: D
options.text: Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. It requires incision and drainage

questions.text: A patient fell from a train onto the railway track and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital, and the following procedure was performed (image shown below). What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
In solid organ transplantation, which of the following organs is associated with a higher incidence of rejection?
